sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the given reaction using the given data:

2H2(g) + O2(g) --> 2H2O(l)

Given:
ΔHf°(H2O(l)) = -285.83 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(O2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the given reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the products, we have 2 moles of H2O(l), and for the reactants, we have 2 moles of H2(g) and 1 mole of O2(g). Using the given standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°), we can plug in the values:

ΔH° = [2 × ΔHf°(H2O(l))] - [2 × ΔHf°(H2(g)) + ΔHf°(O2(g))]

ΔH° = [2 × (-285.83 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (0 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-571.66 kJ) - (0 kJ)

ΔH° = -571.66 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the given reaction is -571.66 kJ.
